Mitigation of carbon monoxide and ammonia to valuable primary aromatic amides is an imperative approach to control the environmentally harmful emissions thereby infusing towards sustainability. Designing of nanostructured catalyst for direct access to the synthetically valuable primary aromatic and heteroaromatic amides via carbonylative amination of aryl halides is always demanding since nano materials can bridge the gap between homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis thus preserving the desirable attributes of both the systems towards sustainable catalysis. Herein, microwave assisted fabrication of highly uniform Pd NPs (3,4 nm) over La-MOFs has been performed and utilized efficiently for ligand free carbonylative amination of aryl iodides with carbon monoxide and ammonia. Moderate to high yields of benzamide derivatives, salicylamide, a drug having analgesic and antipyretic properties were achieved. The unsaturated metal sites in the MOF via synergistic mode of σ and π bonding binds with CO, which significantly enhances the catalytic activity of MOF-composite unlike other supported Pd NPs. DFT confirms the growth of pristine Pd13 cluster within the framework, as active metal center for the carbonylative amination. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Manideepa Sengupta, Subhasis Das, Sumantra Bhattacharya, Md Jahiruddin Gazi, V V D N Prasad, Sk Manirul Islam, * and Ankur Bordoloi.* Highly uniform Pd nanoparticles embedded La based MOF-composite has been synthesized for efficient carbonylative aminations of aryl halides with CO and NH3, utilizing the environmentally harmful emissions towards sustainable products. The unsaturated metal sites in MOF-composite via synergistic mode of σ and π bonding binds CO effectively, which is essential for the superior activity of the Pd@La-MOFs unlike other supported Pd nanoparticles. Keywords CO utilization Pd nanoparticles engraved MOF composite Carbonylative amination Primary aromatic amides Heterogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction Reduction of the environmentally harmful emissions to decrease their devastating impacts on the ecological system has become one of the most vital technological challenges. Its noteworthy to mention that among them CO is one of the most toxic air pollutants generating from the industrial plants and vehicle emissions, owing to the incomplete combustion of the carbon containing fuels [1,2]. Hence, the objective of mitigation to avoid this rapid CO expositions in the atmosphere via CO oxidations and conversions has developed a great interest in the research fields [2,3]. In this context metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have acquired severe attention in the research fields for their exceptional gas uptake properties [4,5], in CO purifications [6], CO oxidation catalysis [5,7]. MOFs are crystalline porous organic-inorganic hybridized materials in which metal ions or metal clusters are connected in a 3D array to the organic linkers with a moderately strong metal-ligand coordination bond [8]. Being extremely versatile materials, owing to the large surface areas, porosity, and properties associated with tuning of structure, synthesis and application of MOFs are always a field of immense interest in the research. However, the applications of MOFs often get constraint due to the decrease in the surface area and absorbance capacity, if exposed to moisture. Additionally, the inherent poor electrical conductivity and narrow micropores limit the diffusion of gas within the pores, which hinders the potentiality of MOF. Synthesis of composites of MOFs is the relevant approach to overcome such deficiencies of MOFs [9]. MOF-composites offer tremendous applications in the areas of gas storage and separation, sensors, batteries, drug delivery, ion-exchange, nanoparticle implantation, and heterogeneous catalysis [8]. The presence of the open metallic sites in the MOFs and MOF-composite unlocks the tremendous gas uptake properties. Fabrication of metal nanoparticles in MOFs is one of the process to generate zero-dimension MOF-composite, where the MOF acting as template induces the growth of NPs and thereby stabilising them on the outer surface [9]. The present work deals with the synthesis and utilization of Pd0 NPs fabricated MOF-composite to catalyse the aminocarbonylation reactions for generation of the essential organo nitrogen compounds, since MOFs have been established as potential solid catalysts to afford nitrogen containing heterocycles [8,10–12]. Pd mediated cross-coupling reactions have become an imperative method to synthesize the organo nitrogen compounds present in the fields of natural products, pharmaceuticals via C-N bond forming reactions. In this context, aminocarbonylation is the single step and elegant catalytic approach to afford the pharmaceutically active heterocyclic amides (some of which are central nervous system active compounds) from the inexpensive feedstocks such as aryl/alkynyl/heteroaryl halides, carbon monoxide and primary or secondary amines/ammonia. Even though there are good number of reports on carbonylative amination over Pd/C supported catalyst, [13] Pd complex anchored ionic liquid grafted on silica matrix, [14] Pd/SiO2 [15], Pd supported triphenyl phospine functionalised polymers, [16] Pd NPs bounded to polymers, [17,18] Pd/MOF-5, [10] and Pd/ZIF-8, [11] however, the catalysis constraints only on aromatic and primary/secondary amines. Use of ammonia gas in aminocarbonylation led to the direct access to the essential primary aromatic and heteroaromatic amides. The dual role of ammonia as a base and nucleophile in aminocarbonylation was established when Wu et al. reported carbonylative amination of aryl bromides on ammonia gas over Pd based homogeneous catalyst system [19,20]. However, to the best of our knowledge there are no reports on aminocarbonylation with ammonia under heterogeneous catalyst system. In this study we wish to report aminocarbonylations with ammonia to afford the aromatic primary amides for the first time over Pd@[La(BTC)H2O]n, since the unsaturated metal sites in MOF via synergistic mode of σ and π bond binds CO effectively. The catalytic activity of the MOF-composite has been compared with the other supported Pd nanoparticles, and a structure-activity relationship has been further established coupled with Density Functional Theory. 2 Experimental section All the chemicals and solvents have been purchased from Merck and used without any further purification. 2.1 Synthesis of La-MOF and Pd@La-MOF In a typical synthesis of La-MOF, 0.5 g of BTC, benzene tricarboxylic acid was added to 30 mL of dimethyl formamide and after complete dissolution, 1.55 g of La(NO3)3٠6H2O was added to the mixture and stirred for 0.5 h. After this, the mixture was transferred into a 50 mL sealed autoclave with Teflon lining and kept at 100 °C for 24 h. After 24 h, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature with a ramp rate of 1֯/min. The white crystalline product was filtered, washed several times with dimethyl formamide and ethanol to eliminate the unreacted reactants and finally dried at 100 °C under vacuum. Fabrication of uniform Pd nanoparticles on La-MOF have been performed by microwave irradiation, in which 0.1 g of La-MOF was added to 50 mL deionised water, followed by addition of 1 × 10−2 mmol of Pd(NO3)2٠xH2O. The mixture was treated under ultrasonication for 5 min, followed by addition of 100 µL hydrazine hydrate. The mixture was then kept under microwave irradiation of 700 W at 45 ֯ °C for 2 min. Here, hydrazine hydrate not only acts as a reducing agent for the palladium ions but also as a capping agent in the process of implantation of Pd nanoparticles within the voids of La-MOF [21]. Finally, the grey colored MOF-composite was filtered, washed with aqueous alcoholic solution and dried under vacuum at 100 °C. A schematic representation of catalyst synthesis has been shown on Scheme 1. 2.2 Aminocarbonylation of aryl halides with Co and NH3 The aminocarbonylation reactions have been performed using Schlenk technique, in 50 mL stainless steel bombs lined with Teflon vessel. At first, 1 mmol of aryl iodide, 1, 4 Dioxane (2 g), 50 mg of Pd@La-MOF (0.5 × 10−2 mmol of Pd) and a magnetic stir bar were taken in the Teflon vessel. The Teflon vessel was then capped with Teflon-cap attached with thermocouple and septum and sealed within the stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was then evacuated and back filled with nitrogen 3,4 times, flushed with NH3 followed by successive cautious addition of 2 bar NH3 and 2 bar CO under ambient temperature. The autoclave was placed in an oil bath and temperature was increased slowly to 130 ֯°C and kept for 24 h with constant stirring. After 24 h, the autoclave was cooled to ambient temperature and the pressure was released slowly and cautiously. A general scheme of the catalytic reaction has been shown on Fig. S1 (Electronic Supplementary Information). The reaction mixture was filtered, and an aliquot was subjected to GC and GC–MS to verify conversion and yield on Thermo Scientific GC TRACE 1300 equipped with a HP5 capillary column of 30 m length, 0.28 mm id, 0.5 mm film thickness and with a flame ionization detector. The programme was started from 50 °C as initial temperature, holding for 2 min, next at 180 °C for 5 min and final temperature at 250 °C, holding for 5 min, with constant ramping rate of 20 °C/min. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structure and morphology of the catalyst The structural composition of the MOF-composite, Pd@La-MOF have been elucidated by XPS analysis, where the survey scan (Fig. 1 a) exposes the peaks for C 1s, O 1s, Pd 3d, La 3d, La 4p, and 4d which predicts the presence of the corresponding C-C/C-H, C-OH, C=O, COO− (carboxylate group of BTC3−) functional moieties and π-π* satellite peak respectively [22]. The presence of BTC3- as structural unit in the MOF-composite has been further predicted from the peak of La-O-COO− at a binding energy 532.4 eV in the deconvoluted O 1 spectrum (Fig. 1c, inset). The difference in the binding energies between 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 peaks in the XP spectrum of La 3d being 3.48 eV, ties with the binding energy of La2(CO3)3 which further predicts the existence of carboxylate groups as BTC3− ligand [22]. The peak at the binding energy 531.2 eV in deconvoluted O 1s spectrum corresponds to the La-O bond. Fig. 1d resembles XP spectrum of Pd 3d with characteristic peaks at binding energies 335.28 and 340.52 eV, correspond to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 peaks of metallic Pd which correlates with the well implantation of Pd0 NPs within the La-MOF framework [22]. FT-IR and Raman spectroscopy also have been performed to confirm the presence of BTC−3 ligand, H2O and DMF in the framework of MOF-composite. The IR spectra of La-MOF, and both fresh and spent Pd@La-MOF (Fig. 2 a) exhibits the characteristic bands for the asymmetric (νCOO − asym) and symmetric (νCOO − asym) vibrations of the carboxylate groups at 1619 cm−1 and 1435 cm−1, 1373 cm−1, respectively [23]. This again signifies the presence of BTC−3 ligand within the framework, which once again correlates with the characteristic Raman bands at 1571 cm−1 and 1467 cm−1 for the asymmetric (νCOO − asym) and symmetric (νCOO − sym) vibrations of carboxylate groups disclosed in Fig. 2b [5]. The broad band around 3448 cm−1 in the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 2a) corresponds to the νOH stretching vibration of the H2O molecules co-ordinated within the La-MOF framework. The existence of DMF within the framework of La-MOF has been predicted from the absorption band around 1662 cm−1 for the vibration of carbonyl group νC=O, [23] absence of which in fresh and spent Pd@La-MOF reveals that the DMF molecules were eliminated under microwave irradiation during the fabrication of Pd0 nanoparticles within the framework. The bands around 1108 cm−1 and 937 cm−1 could be assigned to the in-plane (δCCH) and out-of-plane (γCCH) bending mode vibrations of the aromatic ring of BTC−3 ligand. Moreover, the absorption band around 1540 cm−1 in the IR spectra (Fig. 2a) and 1614 cm−1, and 1010 cm−1 in the Raman spectra (Fig. 2b) correspond to the νC=C vibrations of the aromatic ring associated with the BTC−3 ligand. The Raman bands at 1614 cm−1 and 826.7 cm−1 could be assigned to the out-of-plane bending vibration for C-H. The characteristic absorption bands for BTC−3 ligand and for the solvent molecules in the IR and Raman spectra for spent Pd@La-MOF being identical with that of fresh MOF-composite, indicates that the MOF-composite is stable for aminocarbonylation reaction, and there is no rupture of the MOF structure. The XRD pattern in the Fig. 4, for both the MOF and MOF-composite remain identical predicts that the integrity of the structure of MOF remains intact even after Pd nanoparticles incorporation. The sharp peaks at 2θ around 8.6, 10.7, and 18.4° reveal high crystallinity of La-MOF [5]. In the X-ray diffractogram, owing to the nominal implantation (1%) of Pd0 nanoparticles, characteristic peaks for Pd0 have not been identified or it might have been merged with the peaks of MOF. However, X-ray diffractogram reveals, that in both fresh and spent MOF-composite, the intensity of the peaks for 2θ around 26.5 and 37.9° increases which might be due to the inducement of crystallinity after implantation of Pd0 NPs. Morphology of the MOF-composite and the particle size has been predicted from HRTEM analysis. HRTEM images of fresh Pd@La-MOF (Fig. 3 ) reveals flower-shaped morphology of the MOF-composite, where the rod-shaped MOFs were supposed to be aggregated under microwave irradiation to form such flower like MOF-composite. The Pd0 nanoparticles are finely distributed over the MOF-composite, and the average particle size is 3,4 nm as shown in the particle size distribution histogram (Fig. 3b, inset) and any agglomeration of Pd0 nanoparticles has not been found. In support from the XPS study, HRTEM image also predicts the presence of Pd nanoparticle in metallic state. Fig. 3d reveals the HRTEM image of Pd@La-MOF, where the d-spacing values for Pd nanoparticles are 0.195 and 0.224 nm which correspond to the (200) and (111) plane of metallic Pd (JSPDS Card No. 46-1043). Elemental mapping has been shown in Fig. 3c, which verifies again the uniform distribution of Pd nanoparticles on the La-MOF framework, without any agglomeration. Here, in this microwave assisted fabrication of highly uniform nanoparticles hydrazine hydrate has been used not only as a reducing agent but also as a capping agent, hence Pd0 nanoparticles have been generated over the surface of rods-shaped La-MOF. The HRTEM images of spent Pd@La-MOF (Fig. 5 ) also discloses average size of 3,4 nm Pd0 nanoparticles homogeneously distributed on the aggregated typical rods of La-MOF, which confirms that the Pd0 nanoparticles are suitably stabilized within the MOF. The uniform distribution of the Pd0 nanoparticles has been also verified from the elemental mapping of the spent MOF-composite (Electronic Supplementary Information, Fig. S2). Thermal stability of the MOF-composite has been studied by performing TG and DTG analysis. Fig. 6 represents TG and DTG curves for Pd@La-MOF, which reveal a weight loss around 100–200 °C correspond to the elimination of desorbed water [24]. The structure of MOF is stable up to 480 °C, beyond of which led to the decomposition of the framework. Absence of any weight loss due to DMF within the range 150–200 °C, confirms that the DMF molecules were removed from the pores during microwave assisted Pd nanoparticles incorporation and replaced by water molecules. 3.2 Catalytic properties The potentiality of Pd@La-MOF as catalyst have been established by performing ligand free aminocarbonylations of aryl iodides with direct NH3 and CO, to afford essential benzamide and its derivatives. The reaction conditions were optimized for 48 h, Fig. 7 a represents time on stream (TOS) of the reaction and it was found that conversion of iodobenzene to benzamide in presence of 1% Pd@La-MOF under 4 bar NH3 and 2 bar CO increases steadily and is maximum (around 96%) at 24 h, beyond which conversion remains almost constant. Selectivity towards formation of benzamide is 98% throughout the reaction has been observed, with a minor formation of benzoic acid as side product, which might be due to the adsorbed water molecule within the MOF-composite generated during synthesis. The reaction was also optimized under three different temperatures for 24 h. By keeping the catalyst amount 50 mg (0.5 × 10−2 mmol Pd), NH3 (4 bar) and CO (2 bar) constant, conversion of 1 mmol of iodobenzene increases linearly on rising the temperature from 90 to 110 °C and is maximum at 130 °C. Effect of pressure of NH3 and CO on Pd@La-MOF promoted aminocarbonylation plays a crucial role not only on the selectivity of the targeted benzamide but also on the conversion of iodobenzene. Fig. 7c discloses the pressure effect and it was found that a pressure of 2 bar CO and 2 bar NH3 led to 87% consumption of iodobenzene with 90% selective benzamide formation. Although, the use of increased pressure for CO to 4 bar attempted for a maximum consumption of iodobenzene, however, the selectivity of benzamide dropped to 82%, resulting in the formation of benzoic acid as side product. On controlling a 2 bar CO, and an increase in pressure of NH3 to 4 bar led to an increase in both benzamide selectivity (98%) and iodobenzene conversion (96%). Hence, a pressure of 4 bar NH3 and 2 bar CO have been selected to perform the aminocarbonylation reactions. Similarly, on lowering the catalyst concentration number of active sites decreases, which declined the iodobenzene consumption as reflected in Fig. 7d. Once the reaction condition with Pd@La-MOF was optimized for the effective aminocarbonylation, a variety of substituted aryl iodides have been screened and the corresponding yields and TON for the benzamide derivatives have been presented in Table 1 . Both the activated and deactivated substituents of aryl iodides were found tolerant to the reaction. Electron donating substituents such as -Me, -OMe at the para position gave better yields (Entry 2, 6) compared to that at meta (Entry 4) or ortho (Entry 3, 7) positions. Interestingly, electron withdrawing substituent also found to furnished with promising result (Entry 5). In addition to this, the reaction has been further extended to acquire pharmaceutically active salicylamide (Entry 8), a drug with analgesic and antipyretic properties. Iodo pyridine also found to coupled effectively (Entry 11), however, in case of iodothiopene, side reactions have been noticed with the formation of di-2-thienyl ketone (Entry 10). Further, aryl bromide was also screened and found to afford lower yield under similar condition as presented in . Catalysis with Pd0 NPs supported on various supports have also been screened and the corresponding yields were compared to that of Pd@La-MOF and presented on Fig. 8 b. Pd nanoparticles have been incorporated on the other supports; such as nitrogen rich mesoporous carbon (CNx), Al2O3, carbon nanotubes (CNT), hydrotalcite [Mg6Al2CO3(OH)16•4H2O] via similar synthetic procedure to that od Pd@La-MOF and the aminocarbonylation of aryl iodide with direct CO and NH3 has been performed under the reaction conditions similar to that of Pd@La-MOF maintaining the exact molar ratio of the reactants and catalyst. The conversion, selectivity and yields have been compared on Fig. 8b, which reveals (69–81)% yield of Benzamide derivatives which is much lower in contrast to Pd@La-MOF (∼x223C94%). However, the selectivity towards formation of benzamide remains unaffected, hence the noticeably large conversion of aryl iodide with Pd@La-MOF might be due to the more adsorption of CO within the metal organic frameworks, since active MOF comprises of unsaturated metal sites which via synergistic mode of σ and π bonding, preferentially binds CO [6]. Again, the H2O molecules within the [La(BTC)H2O]n framework may enhance CO adsorption,[25] which has been reflected on the activity. Hence, the support [La(BTC)H2O]n significantly induces the migratory CO insertion into the Ar-Pd bond. A probable catalytic cycle has been shown on Scheme 2 and has been further supported from DFT study. Since the average particle size of Pd@La-MOF is around 4 nm which is corresponding to the Pd13 clusters and hence the DFT calculations have been performed with Pd13. The adsorption of Pd13 on La-MOF has been calculated from the following formula [26]. (1) Δ E binding relax = E LaMOF + Pd − Cluster relax − ( E Pd − Cluster relax + E LaMOF relax ) The calculated adsorption energy of Pd cluster Pd13 over La-MOF has been found to be 1620.3 kcal/mol using Eq. (1), which indicates that the cluster is adsorbed on the La based metal organic framework. Hence, La-MOF provides support to stabilise the Pd cluster within the framework and may play role of the catalyst. The plausible reaction path has been shown on Scheme 2, where the first step involves with the oxidative addition of Pd0 with iodobenzene. Hence, various possible compounds having Pd-Ph and Pd-I bonds may form, the relative stabilities of which have been illustrated on Fig. 9 , however, the species with more stabilization energy will survive. This step accompanies with a small energy barrier of 10 Kcal/mol. The second step comprises with the successive migratory insertion of CO to generate the acyl palladium complex, PhCOPd bond via a reaction barrier 11.2 kcal/mol. The reaction profile for these two steps has been shown on Fig. 10 . In the final step NH3 acting both as base and a nucleophile reacts with the acyl palladium complex to afford the amide, and regenerate Pd° from palladium hydroiodide complex. However, the formation of the amide bond is not a concerted process, rather it undergoes via a couple of transition states and intermediates. In the first step the Lewis base NH3 forms complex with the Pd cluster which is an intermediate molecule (intermediate-1) and N-H bond breaks to form intermediate-2 which subsequently forms benzamide via a favorable transition state. The intermediate-1 may have different geometries, like one Pd atom from the cluster can form bond with H as well as carbonyl carbon (denoted as SC) or two different Pd atoms may be involved to form Pd-H and Pd-C bond (denoted as HC). Their structures are shown in Fig. 11 , but the more stable intermediate structure between these two has been chosen. Their relative energies are shown in parenthesis. As seen from the Fig. 11, the HC (a) intermediate is slightly more stable than the SC (b) intermediate by 2.9 kcal/mol. Further from thermodynamic consideration the difference in zero point corrected negative Gibbs’ free energy (−20.9 kcal/mol) advocates that the formation of Intermediate-1 is favored. The intermediate-1 further formed an anionic species containing amide ion. Herein, like the intermediate-1 different structures of intermediate-2 have been figure out based on the involvement of number of Pd atoms towards the formation of Pd-hetero atom bonds. In the first model structure, one Pd atom is involved in the formation of Pd-C and Pd-N bond simultaneously, and the NH2 anion is almost equidistant from two Pd atoms and is denoted as (1), whereas, in the second structure amide anion forms bond with different Pd and is denoted as (2). The third one is almost similar to that of (1) and is denoted as (3). Their structures (mentioned in parenthesis) along with the relative stabilization energy have been shown on Fig. 12 . The most stable intermediate-2 is also more stable than the intermediate-1 by 4.4 kcal/mol in terms of zero-point corrected Gibbs’ free energy, which indicates that the formation of intermediate-2 is favored from intermediate-1. In the same way the catalyst got recovered by further addition of ammonia. The calculated negative value of change in zero-point corrected Gibbs’ free energy value further indicates the formation of pristine Pd cluster. Even though, these three suitable transition states for the last three steps were not found, but from the thermodynamic point of view the formation of the intermediates and the recovery of the catalyst have been confirmed. To establish the MOF-composite as a true heterogeneous catalyst towards aminocarbonylation of aryl iodides with direct CO and NH3, recycle test up to four cycles and hot filtration test have been screened. On every cycle the reaction has been carried out maintaining the exact molar ratio of the reactants and the catalyst. After each cycle the catalyst was washed thoroughly with ethylacetate to remove the products and unreacted compounds from the catalyst bed followed by washing with aqueous alcoholic solution and drying at 100 °C. Fig. 8a represents the corresponding yield and selectivity of benzamide up to 4 cycles, which reveals the selectivity of the product although remains constant, however, nominal decrease (2,3%) in the product yields have been observed compared to that of fresh catalyst, which might be a due to treatment loss. To perform hot filtration test, after 12 h, the autoclave was cooled, and pressure was released followed by filtration of the MOF-composite. The filtrate containing product and unreacted reactants was again refilled with 2 bar CO and 4 bar NH3 and subjected to 130 °C for another 12 h. Enhancement of yield was not noticed in the next 12 h (Fig. 8c) which confirms the well confinement of the Pd0 NPs within the La-MOF framework and absence of metal leaching as verified from ICP-AES proves the heterogeneity of the catalyst system. 4 Conclusion Mitigation of toxic CO and NH3 has been carried out to access the synthetically valuable primary aromatic amides over MOFs intending towards formation of sustainable products, since MOFs with open metallic sites possesses tremendous gas uptake properties. Zero-dimension MOF-composite of Pd0 NPs embedded on {[La(BTC)H20]DMF}n rods have been fabricated under microwave irradiation, which led to the elimination of the DMF molecules from the framework and aggregation of the rods to form flower-shaped [La(BTC)H20]n with highly uniform 3,4 nm Pd0 NPs. The MOF-composite was then effectively utilized in the catalysis towards formation of benzamide and its derivatives, which are essential pharmaceutically active organo nitrogen compounds via ligand-free aminocarbonylation of aryl iodides with direct CO and NH3. The reaction conditions with 1% Pd@La-MOF have been optimized and found to provide maximum yields and large TON at 130 °C under 2 bar CO and 4 bar NH3 along with the recyclability of the catalyst system up to four cycles. A comparative study with different solid supported Pd0 NPs has been also performed to establish the efficiency of the MOF-composite. The unsaturated metal sites in the active metal organic frameworks via synergistic mode of σ and π bonding binds the CO, thereby enhancing adsorption of CO within the framework which remarkably influences the formation of acyl palladium complex associated with the aminocarbonylation. DFT further predicts the growth of pristine Pd13 clusters within the La based metal organic framework. The Pd13 clusters are stabilised by the organic linkers, which obstructs leaching of the same in the reaction mixture, hence the MOF-composite has been found as a truly heterogeneous and sustainable catalyst system towards effective aminocarbonylation. coredata.dc:description: Mitigation of carbon monoxide and ammonia to valuable primary aromatic amides is an imperative approach to control the environmentally harmful emissions thereby infusing towards sustainability. Designing of nanostructured catalyst for direct access to the synthetically valuable primary aromatic and heteroaromatic amides via carbonylative amination of aryl halides is always demanding since nano materials can bridge the gap between homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis thus preserving the desirable attributes of both the systems towards sustainable catalysis. Herein, microwave assisted fabrication of highly uniform Pd NPs (3,4 nm) over La-MOFs has been performed and utilized efficiently for ligand free carbonylative amination of aryl iodides with carbon monoxide and ammonia. Moderate to high yields of benzamide derivatives, salicylamide, a drug having analgesic and antipyretic properties were achieved. The unsaturated metal sites in the MOF via synergistic mode of σ and π bonding binds with CO, which significantly enhances the catalytic activity of MOF-composite unlike other supported Pd NPs. DFT confirms the growth of pristine Pd13 cluster within the framework, as active metal center for the carbonylative amination.
coredata.dc:title: Sustainable synthesis of drug intermediates via simultaneous utilization of carbon monoxide and ammonia over Pd@La-MOF
